qas.question: What is an example of a device that requires more than 500 mA of current?
What is an issue that may occur if a high-speed external disk drive is powered from just one USB 2.0 port.
What does USB compliance specification prohibit?

answers.text: "use of a 'Y' cable (a cable with two A-plugs)

context: Some devices, such as <a0_0>high-speed external disk drives<a0_0/>, require more than 500 mA of current and therefore <a1_0>may have power issues<a1_0/> if powered from just one USB 2.0 port: erratic function, failure to function, or overloading/damaging the port. Such devices may come with an external power source or a Y-shaped cable that has two USB connectors (one for power and data, the other for power only) to plug into a computer. With such a cable, a device can draw power from two USB ports simultaneously. However, USB compliance specification states that <a2_0>"use of a 'Y' cable (a cable with two A-plugs)<a2_0/> is prohibited on any USB peripheral", meaning that "if a USB peripheral requires more power than allowed by the USB specification to which it is designed, then it must be self-powered."
